description.text:
This OpenSCAD script will generate a Tiffany Etoile style ring with a tension/Bezel/Partial-Bezel set jewel mount for a brilliant (round) cut diamond or similar shiny thing.
Most parameters are user selectable as are the ring profile shapes. Potentially very useful when combined with the following:
Ring metal cost calculator http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12589
Diamond size shape weight conversion Spreadsheet http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12586
Ring Size System Coversion http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12689
for creating and costing a custom engagement ring or other such tomfoolery. Todo:
add option to round edges on crown
make gap between 2 sides of crown slightly smaller than required to exert pressure on sides of jewel to hold it in place for proper tension set performance
add complete roman font polygons for engraving
implement hidden compartment Warning:
Let the right one in Changes from previous versions:
0.14
  • Replaced deprecated import_stl with import
  • Added control variable "generate_jewel", if 0 import the jewel from "brilliant1.stl", else try to generate it on-the-fly (this may cause errors as pointed out by mrchriseyes)
    0.13
  • Added Simple internal engraving functionality (you will need to create a custom polygonal script though!)
  • Finally got the person's ACTUAL ring size!6 6- USA
  • Grooves for diamond were too small Need to scale stone by about 1.07 to acount for diameter loss
    0.12
  • Added Secondary Crown to make it more similar to Tiffany Etoile Solitaire
  • Used Render() and gave option to load the Brilliant cut Diamond shape from external STL file for better previews (the complexity was causing CSG rendering to be disabled)
  • Added additional code to ensure the inner surface of the ring is preserved and smooth as crown shapes could poke through, creating sharp edges on inside of ring
  • Fixed colours on certain areas
    0.11
  • Fixed issue whereby rounded rectangle shape CS appeared slightly translated in Y direction (taken from Ring_band_creation_script_v1.1.scad)
  • Added extra cross sections (cs_half_pill, cs_reverse_hemi_ellipse, cs_reverse_rounded_hemi_ellipse taken from Ring_band_creation_script_v1.1.scad)
    0.10
  • Round edges on cylinder unched through centre of crwon to back of ring
  • Add option to have side supports on crown
    0.9
  • Added user variable to control colour and opacity of jewel and metal material
  • Can select which type of split you want for the crown (none, rectangular, bowtie, both) by setting with_bowtie_split and with_rectangular_split to 00, 01, 10 or 11 respectively
  • Can now choose whether crown is splayed out/tapered or not
  • Finally remembered to difference the brilliant cut gem from the ring to make the groove to hold the brilliant cut round jemstone
  • Added ability to specify diamond size in Carats to specify girdle diameter, assuming a round cut close to ideal it should be reasonalby accurate (based on data from http://d.neadiamonds.com/diamond-carat). Relationship appears to be close to power or logarithmic curve
  • Power Curve size[mm]=6.5065412147(Carat^0.3381325352), confidence value R^2=0.998
  • Log Curve size[mm]=1.964367652 Ln(Carat) + 6.6289134546
  • Changed most crown variables so that they are influenced by the size of the stone chosen
  • De-deprecated some variables
  • Added new cross sectional shape cs_rounded_scallopped_rectangle
    0.8
  • Added outwards splay/taper to jewel setting based on size of crown face and size of ring
  • Identified some redundant variables
  • Added additional cross sectional shapes (chamfered rectangle)
  • Fixed some CS that resulted in internal diamteres less than expected (cs_rounded_hemi_ellipse, cs_rounded_rectangle, cs_chamfered_rectangle)
    0.7
  • Added ring sizes from 4 systems based on linearisation of data found here http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ring_size
  • Added acitional cross sectional shapes (rounded rectangle and chamfered rectangle)
    0.6
  • Added multiple user selectable cross sections (rect, ellipse, D, chamfered, filleted, scallopped)
    0.5
  • Added ability to make a bowtie shaped cutout through the jewel mount and ring, 'cause it looks cool!
  • Added ability to color the ring & crown part of the eh... ring!?
    0.4
  • Fixed issue with internal diameter of ring not being that specified by user
  • Added ability to control width of rectangular split/cutout on jewel mount
  • Added ability to control depth that jewel mount overlaps band of ring
  • Changed cylindrical cutout in jewel mount to be conical
  • Added an actual scalable brilliant cut diamond shape (with ability to give it a "color") within the jewel mount(pretty!)
    0.3
  • Changed to pill shaped cross section
  • Added rectangular cutout on jewel mount to make split/tension set type fitting, it doesn't line up correctly though :(
  • Added commented out/empty calls to functions to enable rest of functionality I desire
    0.2
  • I don't think I ever got around to changing this version, please ignore this :p
    0.1
  • First attempt
  • Makes rectangular cross section ring with hollow cylindrical shaped mount for jewel
  • Allows user to define feature size

• Steal target's rings/get their ring size
  • Acquire jewel carat weight or size (diameter) in mm
  • Decide on cross section type, ring band width, depth and feature size, crown diameter and ring sizing system
  • Modify "user variables" section of script with these values
  • Render your custom ring
    5a. Print in plastic and hope your target cares not for material value
    or
    5b. Print in metal using a service like shapeways and hope your target cares not for hallmarks
    or
    5c. Find reputable jewel merchant/metalsmith/ring maker etc. to bring your item to life professionally so their will be little room for complaints

comments.text: The code I wrote to generate the diamond is a bit messy and old and gives OpenSCAD trouble. There is the option to load the diamond shape from an external .stl file rather than generates the diamond within the OpenSCAD file. To do this you would have to edit in-out some lines, but I have made a new version for you (0.14) that gives you control over this using the "generate_jewel" variable, try changing this from 0 to 1 and seeing which works for you.
comments.author: mrchrisreyes

comments.text: I just ordered a copy of v0.13 in silver from Shapeways as a prototype. Hopefully it'll turn out well!
comments.author: M_G

comments.text: After ordering v0.13 in Silver from Shapeways I purchased suitably sized brilliant cut cubic zirconia and when all the parts EVENTUALLY found their way through the postal system and cleared customs I had it set by a jeweller. The bottom tip of of the CZ had no cutlet and in setting the gem the mount was deformed and pressed down slightly. This left a sharp point on the inner surface of the ring which makes it uncomfortable to wear. However it served as a good reference for the next step in the process...
comments.author: M_G

comments.text: As I came across this many years too late, but the issues described are the same with the original Tiffany design. In 1999 I had the original full bezel design custom made to fit a 3ct diamond I had  inherited and the jeweler had to shave the diamond in order to make it work. I was told the setting was redesigned with cuts in the bezel to allow more light to pass through the stone because of that issue. It's still a great looking design nonetheless.
comments.author: M_G

comments.text: Hmmm...normally a ring is adjusted to suit a diamond, but it sounds like they also adjusted the diamond (based on what you said I guess they polished down the tip making the cutlet larger) to fit the ring in your case. That'd make me nervous, especially for such a large stone, glad your ring looked alright in the end.

One of the simpler model aircraft I've built, this is a great gift idea for kids who are beginning to show interest in aviation. I made this as a gift for a relative's nephew who's eyes bugged out of his head when I gave them an E190 for Christmas. This is the largest single-aisle airliner built by Boeing.
Any trouble? Let me know!
Version 1.0.8 - The all-in-one print file has been created, with the innovation and updates of newer models applied retroactively. Turbine blades are included in that list of updates, as well as a few modeling issues I've discovered.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

10% 0.4mm Diamond (fast)

Notes: Print the fuselage in 0.2mm Standard Resolution, and the wings and enginestabs in 0.1mm High Resolution. I recommend 4 shells for the model for strength and to avoid gaps.

Build Details Build time for this model was about three hours in Sketchup. The process remains the same as my other model aircraft, and applies to only Sketchup as I have not tried the same build process in other CAD programs. The key is getting the dimensions of the "virtual hangar" correct, in terms of scale, height and length. All three sides have to match in scale to one another, or you'll have great trouble in drawing the components.

Replacement stones for a Tsukuda Othello board (I assume they are compatible across multiple Tsukuda boards.)
Over time, I lost quite a few stones, so I finally decided to replicate 11 of them, so I can now play a full game with my son.
I only printed the 'straight' version, so the sides are (much) easier to mass-polish. No glue is necessary with a good tight fit.

Now you can show the world your beloved drumsticks on your wall (or wherever you want).
This holder is customizable, so it works for almost any drumstick, and any number of them you want to hold.
It also can be attached to a surface by using screws, editing a single parameter on the code.

1-Download the .scad file and edit it. You can configure:
d: diameter of the drumstick (you may want to set it a little bigger, as it will fit better)
n: number of drumstick the holder will support
screw_support: (true/false) if true, it creates a extra support so you can use screws to attach the holder to a surface.
2 - Compile it to a .stl file
3 -Print it!!

Our earlier support is broken, and I have some T Slot profiles...
So I design this support, the circular piece hold the filter, square parts are for mounting 20mm T slots, she told me to make a modular support, for better clean and another reasons.
Each foot have 300mm taller. From my use

And sorry for my horrible english.

Minha noiva costuma dizer "O café fica muito melhor, se feito no filtro de tecido"
Como nosso antigo suporte quebrou, resolvi construir um novo com alguns perfis de alumínio que eu tinha sobrando.
A ideia do suporte é apoiar o filtro em uma peça circular, as partes quadradas, são pra encaixar o perfil de alumínio no corpo principal do suporte.
Ela me pediu pra criar uma peça desmontável, por ser mais prático de limpar e guardar.
Pro nosso uso, fiz cada pé com 300mm de altura. Mas você pode adequar às suas necessidades.

The square junctions from the foot and the circle part is tight, but thats is the idea, I'm dont like if they loose when I'm making the coffee.

title: QUBD TwoUp Z axis 2nd motor mod

description.text:
Got tired of the sagging X axis and the pulley mod is limited in help.
Remixed Stephanburger parts and modified them so they mirror correctly and the idle pulle screw faces the back now.
Big difference in quality! 0.05 mm layers using a 0.25 mm hot end. Made 20 layers thin lithopanes with this mod without any problems.
Note that you need to move the existing Y axis motor to the center of the base together with the belt. That will also get rid of the "sideways jerk" that this printer has (someone else came up with the idea, don't remember so chime in). My platform is now made of aluminum since the original fiber board was warping. Tried a 3d printed one but wasn't straight enough for my liking.

Instructions You will need to move the Y axis motor and belt to the base as shown (someone else came up with the idea)
Parts needed:
-Stepper motor (connect in parallel to existing Z motor)
-Drive screw (from QUBD or other source)
-Drive nut (QUBD or others)
-Coupler (QUBD or others) Also, print a couple of screws to cover the top and bottom (Stephanburger parts)

description.text: The purpose of this project was to create a 3D acrylic object using the laser engraver.  I love wearing rings so I decided to create a funky square ring.  After some trial and error, I discovered that a ring size of 9 worked best for me, so I used this size diameter when designing the ring using Autodesk Inventor software.  I'm happy with the way that it turned out and the neat effect of using one red layer of acrylic sandwiched between two clear layers, so the ring appears to have a different opacity when viewed from different angles.

This project was created with a 40 watt Epilog Engraver; the vector cutting was set to 12% speed, 100% power, and 5000 Hz frequency.  Three acrylic layers (2 clear, 1 red) were cut and then clamped and glued together with acrylic glue.

title: Ikea Nyvoll Bed Post Caps
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I got tired of banging my shins on the corner of the bed posts that stick out at the foot of my Ikea Nyvoll bed. So I created a pair of round caps for them. They print upside down (which means a flat part on top), and just slide down onto the top of each post. The idea is that you are putting a spherical top cap on each bed post that smooths both the top and sides, making the corners round to reduce the pain of bumping into them. No shin bruises since I put these on!  
There is an extra millimeter or so of slop on the fit so you won't scratch up the wood getting them on and off. It's the first 3D object I've made, so no doubt can be improved, but gets the job done as is.  (The inside is a hollow sphere to save material and add strength, but it has a square resting place for the square top of the post to fit securely.)

I printed with 3 shells and 0.1 fill to use a bit less material than 0.2, and they worked fine in ABS.  
The left and right are basically mirror images of each other, so you'll probably want one of each if you have this type of bed. Looks like the way the file uploaded you'll need to rotate to get the flat part facing down on the build platform (e.g., 270 degrees X rotation and then "Center Objekt" with Repetier). No support needed.

Maybe I will do this..... 04/01/2016 Original Light Pull Switch Weight
05/01/2016 Scaled Up Light Pull Switch Weight
07/01/2016 LightBulb Motif Pull Switch Weight
08/01/2016 LighBulb Motif Pull Switch Weight (no thread)
11/01/2016 Extractor Fan Pull Switch Weight This is a good little demo of how mass produced moulded design is different from 3D Printed Design. in this case it isn't Injection moulds, most (UK) electrical polymer parts are made from Thermoset materials. Where Thermoplastic get softer when heated, Thermoset only polymerise once, when two reagents are pressurised and heated in the mould. This makes the parts safer for electrical usage, as if the parts where to get softer as they heat, they might deform and cause electrical contact. So Thermosets are generally used to contain electrical connections for safety reasons. Please remember this when downloading electrical stuff: 3D PRINTERS USE THERMOPLASTICS. Next up in my monologue: Angles of Draft. On 3D Prints, you don't have to remove the part from a complex (and expensive) tool, but on the Compression Moulding tools, you can't remove parts with undercut. Ideally designed parts would have no draft on them (for most parts) - it's only added on to make either Die Casting, Injection Moulding or Compression Moulding. 3D Printing allows us to make parts closer to the ideal form - in some instances. In Other ways, we need to add either Support Structure to be broken away or washed off, or design it to be self-supporting. The original Pull Switch Weights are made from Thermoset polymer, simply to get parts from the same supplier who makes the other thermoset parts. They don't have to be Thermoset. I've designed these to be 3D printed replacements for the original Pull Switch Cords. Enjoy. -EUR ING. Andy Southern aka BathRobotics.

title: NES-350-12 Power Supply Cover with Switch

description.text: This cover is designed for the MeanWell NES-350-12 power supply and is equipped to fit This Fused IEC320 Switch or any other switch that uses a 30x50mm cut out and has two mounting screws on 50mm centers. This power supply cover includes cutouts for all vents as well as all 3mm and 4mm mounting points. I used some random tiny 2mm machine screws that were in my spare parts box to attach the switch. Depending on what screw you use to secure the switch plate, you may need to drill out the pilot holes to fit. The six holes across the front are 2 @ 6mm and 4 @ 4mm to accommodate 12awg and 16awg wiring in a clean and organized way. (For heated bed, Ramps, etc...) Solder your AC wires to the switch at 90-degree angles (pictured,) to be sure that you will have enough clearance. I also used the stock transparent MeanWell terminal cover inside for an extra layer of short-circuit protection.

This is a simplified model derived from a 3D study of a fossilized dinosaur track from the Glen Rose digsite. The track model was used with Sugru and the open-source equivalent Oogoo (http://www.instructables.com/id/How-To-Make-Your-Own-Sugru-Substitute/) to create stamps for making dino tracks on paper as part of the SOLID Learning (http://SOLIDLearning.org) workshops theme "Making Tracks" and the form model is been used by several teachers to model Jell-o(tm) tracks (food safe materials used) for workshop lunches and to make hand-out cast track examples for kids to take him at their own classes. Dr. Louis Jacobs of SMU together with Dr. James Brooks have shared their original scan for the world and were very happy to allow this simplified model to be shared publicly here for educational purposes. My thanks goes out to both of these gentlemen for their generosity in sharing this excellent example of preservation and curation of delicate solid forms from the distant past! The positive mold was reduced by 50% in the z-axis to reduce the volume of Sugru/Oogoo needed for each track. The negative mold is proper by all proportions to allow dough used for making cookies and brownies, each with its own dinosaur track. One teacher filled these tracks with icing, but others say the kids seem to enjoy the crackling surface of the brownie well too. Make sure you print using food safe materials or seal the object fully using food safe varnishes or food-rated silicone molding agents. Not a commercial endorsement, but I have used molding material from Reynolds Advanced Materials designed for casting edible sugar forms in the past with good results to make food-safe molds from 3D printed objects.

I have a MendelMax 2.0 printer, which, like several other printers, is built with an extruded aluminum frame. One of the great things about these extruded aluminum frames is that you can easily attach things to them using bolts and T nuts. So why not bolt a spool holder onto my frame?  
I created this spool holder to handle 1kg spools. The two bearings allow the spool to rotate freely and very smoothly.  
I've tested this with Ultimachine 1Kg spools, and it works with either orientation of the spool. I have not tried with other makes of spools.

Print out the part as shown in the photo, and oriented in the STL file. You'll need the following hardware:
  • 2 M8x25 bolts
  • 2 M8 nuts
  • 4 M8 washers
  • 2 608Z bearings
  • 2 M5 T nuts
  • 2 M5x8 bolts
    • Place one M8 washer on each side of a 608 bearing and place into the slot as shown in the photo. You can insert the M8 bolt through the large hole on eaither end. Fasten in place with an M8 nut, as shown. Insert the M5 bolts into the spool holder from the front, and then add the M5 T nuts to the back, keeping them very loose. Finally, slide the T nuts into the beam's channel and tighten.

description.text:
This is a replacement for a GoPro mount. I don't know which mount exactly. Also the parts are probably not scaled perfectly - since we had to adjust for ABS shrinkage we scaled both of them up by 5% before printing. Theoretically, if you print in something less shrinking it should be enough.
If anyone requires them, I can maybe post the Solidworks files.

Printer:

Kossel 2020

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1-0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes: I printed the lower bracket part (Unterseite) with supports such that the biggest part of the model hits the plate and the big horizontal hole is on top. I rotated it -90° around the x-axis. Shell settings:
  • 4 solid bottom + top layers
  • 3 shells
    • Nozzle:
    0.3mm nozzle - the model is not designed with a specific extrusion width in mind. It should be printable by nearly any nozzle. Support settings in Simplify3D were:
  • Infill 30%
  • Extra inflation Distance: 1,4mm
  • Dense support layers: 3
  • Horizontal offset: 0.7mm - better more than less
  • Upper vertical separation layers: 2 - shoulda been 1

Not required Post-process the parts with Acetone. This will make it much stronger - this model only exists because the original part broke on first (!) use. You really don't want to break more than a few :) It will generally make the parts last longer since there are no more loose strings around which can, like clothes, pull away more strings if you don't have perfect layer adhesion etc.

A cyclone dust separator extracts dust and debris using a vortex effect instead of a filter. The debris is collected in its own container (easy to discard in trash) and as a result it greatly reduces the clogging of the main shop vacuum bags or filters.  
This device is particularly useful for CNC/Machining/Woodworking environments but the applications are more varied.  
This design is in a very experimental state, no data on the efficiency at this time (standard cyclonic theory should apply), but some testing shows it does a good job with aluminum chips from my CNC.   
Note: As my first attempt at cyclonic separation, this was designed independently / from scratch but in the meantime thing 119410 was uploaded here so I'll credit that (not just because the design is sufficiently similar and was uploaded earlier, but I'd also like to integrate some of its features in my design now).

Just print out of your least favorite filament, preferably with a wall thickness of 2 or above to resist abuse in a shop environment (my first printed cyclone with 1mm wall thickness cracked at the first serious drop).  
A Shopvac version of this (45mm input hose) might require a print volume of 8x8x8 inches or more.  
The design seems very resilient to decompression: a powerful vacuums (eg "5HP") might implode typical PET bottle (like the one in the image) but the cyclone retains its shape.  
I have not yet experimented with smoothing (of the interior cyclone) but in theory it should help increase efficiency because the decreased friction.

comments.text: Nice design, thanks for sharing it! Why did you use $fn=100 for some parts and $fn=33 for others?
comments.author: balassy

comments.text: It's been almost 4 years since I designed this but I believe the intent at the time was to produce a smooth (close to round) cone to reduce friction while still making the non-critical parts render fast in OpenSCAD. You can probably bump this higher nowadays.

comments.author: tyman00

comments.text: I really like this design..  I downloaded the scad-file, changed the parameter for the shopvac-side, remixed a threaded part onto the hopper so I had an airtight seal for a bottle.. printed it and then realized that when the vacuum_diameter is changed, the diameter of the dust collection collector is changed as well.. maybe not so clever, if one wants to use a specific hose for the dust collection? fortunately I didn't have a specific hose in mind when I printed mine, but others should be aware of this.. keeping those two as separate options would make this really great.
comments.author: renelm

comments.text: very cool... so, if I wanted to build one to work with drink bottles like you have in the picture, what settings should I use?  Also, has anyone tried this with any bigger bottle openings, like a gatorade bottle?
comments.author: lordmundi

comments.text:
I am remote right now and cannot check, but I would recommend measuring the bottle with a caliper, then cut the object and print just the neck and see if it fits well, as there are small variations from printer to printer. There is no thread so the insulation is not perfect right now, I will try to post an updated version that threads in.
One thing to be careful about is the negative pressure that develops because of the vacuum: that can cause thin-walled bottles (like Gatorade) to collapse/implode.
comments.author: lordmundi

description.text:
This is a mount for a common mechanical switch. If your endstops are simple mechanical switches, this is an easy way to attach them to the Cupcake's opto-endstop mount points. They do require a slightly longer flag for the X-Axis, as the Opto's interrupt point was below the screw. You will need:
-2x M3x16 screws and nuts (20mm may be better) like those that came with the Cupcake.
-2x M2x10 screws and nuts - I would recommend getting a screws to match your switch's width.
-2x Limit switch - There are lots of manufacturers for these. I got mine at a surplus store. The mount holes in these are different distances apart, but most I've seen are 2mm.

Corner connector to join Makerslide with 20x20mm extrusion.

In the process of expanding the worksurface of my ShapeOko, I needed a bracket to join the Makerslide to 20x20mm extrusion.  
There are 4 pieces needed: 2 right brackets and 2 left brackets  
Assemble as shown in the photos, mounting the baseplate to the Makerslide first.  
It is set up for M5 x 10mm machine screws; it works but it's a little tight with the socket head screws.  Button head screws will give a little more working room, but the socket screws work fine, if a bit fiddly.  
Use of sandpaper and shims may be required for best alignment.  
These should also work with 20x60 and larger extrusions.

description.text:
Another mini for the wargame I'm working on, designed to hold captured prisoners/corpses in underslung area and then reanimate them for use later in the game.  
As always, C&C and remixes are appreciated! I don't have a printer yet, so please let me know how I can make this more printer-friendly!

Made using Tinkercad.  
To assemble, print 8 Legs, 8 Ribs, 2 Snipper Arms, 4 Snippers, 2 Mandible Pincers, and 1 of everything else.  
Legs can be attached at any of the three provided levels on the Ribs, and you can add more legs for a more centipede-y feel!

title: QuickFit Attachment for Rotoflex rotary tool flex attachment

description.text: This allows the attachment of a Rotoflex tool attachment to a "quickfit" xcarriage base or my version the "Twistfit" base. Rotoflex attachment works with dremel type rotary tools.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16627 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=16627
